ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 2: Simulation exercises were helpful, but written assignment workload was too heavy for a 1-credit course.
I find the course Collaboration & Conflict Skills extremely helpful for me, not only as an environmental professional, but also as someone who is interested in working in an international setting.

This course did not address conflict resolution. It addressed meeting organization/ preparation and how integral that is to leading groups of people. It was too short to address actual conflict resolution and the simulations were not very effective- except to show that negotiation is a long, frustrating process. If you have NO background in conflict res you may find this semi useful. Otherwise, it is just too broad.
Great course content - wish there had been a bit more time to delve into some of the topics in more detail.
The course should be a full-semester, three-credit course to make out the most of it.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Sharing of real life negotiation scenarios.
Ona and the exercises. The negotiation specifically was really fun to do and get a feel for.
In-class exercises
Group assignments
Ona is patient and receptive and there are great snacks.
The simulations were the best aspect of this course. This is where the learning happened.
Practice conflict simulations
The interactive exercises with fellow students.
The group assignments based on real cases.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Make it longer, and cover more scope.
Some of the out-of-class exercises seemed like they lacked relevancy, or were too conceptual/"on paper" to be as useful as they could be for us working in environmental fields
We need more time
This class should be longer, have specific tools to teach students, work with real people instead of simulations.
Simulations should be done earlier in the semester. The one day long class was good but perhaps should not coincide with midterms.

Would be great to have a deeper dive into some of the subjects (Perhaps, role-playing in the best ways to hold a multi-stakeholder meeting. While the simulations were helpful, would be great to see something modeled to provide ideas of how to best resolve.).
The duration, it should be longer to allow for more learning and internalizing of the concepts taught.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes.
Yes.
The group assignments ended up taking up a lot of time, and though I found them helpful, I wonder if there is a way to get the learning in a more confined amount of time.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Negotiation is central to any aspect of work and everyone should take this course to equip themselves with an essential life skill.
Plan to work with lots of different groups with different views on what is right and how things should move forward, so it was really valuable.
My career path involves the facilitation of negotiations among a number of stakeholders.
Very useful for almost any area of environmental studies - in terms of understanding how best to operate within and on behalf future organizations.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: This course is a requirement for the Specialization in Land Management, Use and Policy
Required part of the MF program.
To learn -how to facilitate dialogue among parties of varying interests -to negotiate -the tools and their use in running an effective meeting
To improve planning aspects of organizing and managing meetings and to learn how to figure out interests of different parties and how to try to find a common ground.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Sort of...now I know about effective meeting facilitation, but there wasn't much content about conflict resolution at a more serious or broader level.
Exceeded my expectations
yes
Yes.
EXCEEDED

I gained some valuable knowledge and skills about negotiation and conflict which is important for any situation. It was less environmentally focused then I expected, but the skills are widely applicable
Yes.
Yes
No- they did not meet them.
Yes,however it was only the surface. I wish it were a full class so I could learn more and delve deeper into refining these skills.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group work was an integral part of the class. It was well-designed.
Learning negotiation.

One reason was that TAs arranged the groups other than people voluntarily forming their own groups. In too many cases, people set up groups with someone they had already known well and were not motivated to reach out to people they had not talked much with. I have seen it several times in other classes where US students form groups among themselves while international students ended up in one group. I understand that people would prefer working in groups that they feel comfortable with, and I have the same feeling often times, but I have been wondering how much the loss of different perspectives could be.
My group was great- but often confused on the process of conflict res to go through.

The structure of the class enabled us all to work in different groups which was good because we all got to experience the nuances of working with people of different backgrounds and personalities. This provided me with the space to also observe my contributions, reactions and interactions based on the dynamics of the group. I did not notice any disadvantages.
Positive and challenging learning environment. Challenge to schedule each exercise.
Very, very helpful - the role-playing games were one of the most valuable parts of the course for me.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: fun and useful!
Just do it.
seriously take this course. great no matter what you are doing.
Take it!
You will not learn how to successfully mediate a conflict at the end of this course. You will learn how to lead a meeting.
The readings are very helpful. Try your best to make all of the classes. They are very useful. Do the written assignments early.

This course will provide a good survey of the conflict resolution and consensus building field, and if you already have a background in such, you may want to fully consider if this course is the best fit.
Helpful introduction to basic premises of negotiation and collaboration - more of a broad overview than a deep dive into these topics.
To take it, it is a great course.
